required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Light Therapy for Moderate Traumatic Brain Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Low Level Light Therapy (LLLT) With Near Infrared Light Emitting Diodes in Patients With Moderate Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to find out if a specialized helmet that provides low levels of near infrared light, also known as low-level light therapy (LLLT) has any effect on the recovery of people who have recently (within 72h) suffered a moderate traumatic brain injury (TBI).

detailed_description.textblock: The specific aim of this pilot study is to determine the feasibility of using the LLLT helmet in patients with moderate TBI and to quantify the response to LLLT using magnetic resonance (MR) and clinical outcome measures. We hypothesize that we will be able to quantify the response to LLLT through MR imaging and clinical outcome measures.

primary_outcome.measure: Safety and Feasibility of Applying Light Therapy After Moderate TBI
primary_outcome.time_frame: up to seven days after enrollment
primary_outcome.description: Number of subjects to successfully complete light therapy without serious unanticipated adverse events related to application of the device.

secondary_outcome.measure: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on MRI Using the Fazekas Scale for Periventricular White Matter (PVWM)
secondary_outcome.description: The presence of chronic white matter disease was evaluated using Fazekas scale. The scale divides the white matter in periventricular and deep white matter, and each region is given a grade depending on the size and confluence of lesions. periventricular white matter (PVWM). 0 = absent = "caps" or pencil-thin lining = smooth "halo" = irregular periventricular signal extending into the deep white matter A neuroradiologist evaluated the 3D T2-SPACE-FLAIR images to detect the presence of T2 hyperintensities and their degree (0: absent; 1: mild; 2: moderate; and 3: severe) for PVWM. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on MRI Using the Fazekas Scale for Deep White Matter (DWM)
secondary_outcome.description: The presence of chronic white matter disease was evaluated using Fazekas scale. The scale divides the white matter in periventricular and deep white matter, and each region is given a grade depending on the size and confluence of lesions. deep white matter (DWM) 0 = absent = punctate foci = beginning confluence = large confluent areas A neuroradiologist evaluated the 3D T2-SPACE-FLAIR images to detect the presence of T2 hyperintensities and their degree (0: absent; 1: mild; 2: moderate; and 3: severe) for DWM. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on Neurcognitive Function
secondary_outcome.time_frame: RPQ scores were collected at approx 72 hours, 14 days, 3 months, and 6 months and the mean was calculated for the values reported.
secondary_outcome.description: RPQ is a 16 item self-assessment questionnaire completed via an in-person or phone interview. Each item in the questionnaire is assessed on a 5-point scale ranging from 0 (no problem) - 4 (severe problem). The questions are grouped in two non-overlapping sets: the RPQ-3 includes early, objective, physical symptoms, and the RPQ-13 group includes later, more cognitive and behavioral symptoms. The RPQ-3 encompasses headache, dizziness, and nausea/vomiting. The RPQ-13 includes questions evaluating noise sensitivity, sleep disturbance, fatigue, irritability, depressed mood, forgetfulness, poor concentration, longer thinking time, blurred vision, light sensitivity, double vision, and restlessness. The RPQ-3 ranges from 0 - 12 (best to worst) and RPQ-13 ranges from 0 - 52 (best to worst). RPQ Total is the theoretical max/min RPQ score with a combined possible score ranging from 0-64 (best to worst). The outcome measures are

arm_group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated.
A helmet containing near infrared LEDs (LLLT helmet) will be applied and the LEDs will be turned on/activated

intervention.description: LED helmet applied with light activated
LED helmet applied without light activated

group.title: Non-active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated. Non-active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied without light activated

group.title: Active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LEDs (LLLT helmet) will be applied and the LEDs will be turned on/activated Active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied with light activated

group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated. Non-active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied without light activated

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Safety and Feasibility of Applying Light Therapy After Moderate TBI
outcome.description: Number of subjects to successfully complete light therapy without serious unanticipated adverse events related to application of the device.
outcome.time_frame: up to seven days after enrollment
outcome.population: Subjects who completed light or sham treatment and at least one MRI scan. 43 patients completed the study with at least one MRI scan, 19 subjects in the Light treatment group and 24 subjects in the sham treatment group.

group.title: Non-active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated. Non-active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied without light activated

group.title: Active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LEDs (LLLT helmet) will be applied and the LEDs will be turned on/activated Active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied with light activated

measure.title: Safety and Feasibility of Applying Light Therapy After Moderate TBI
measure.description: Number of subjects to successfully complete light therapy without serious unanticipated adverse events related to application of the device.
measure.population: Subjects who completed light or sham treatment and at least one MRI scan. 43 patients completed the study with at least one MRI scan, 19 subjects in the Light treatment group and 24 subjects in the sham treatment group.

outcome.title: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on MRI Using the Fazekas Scale for Periventricular White Matter (PVWM)
outcome.description: The presence of chronic white matter disease was evaluated using Fazekas scale. The scale divides the white matter in periventricular and deep white matter, and each region is given a grade depending on the size and confluence of lesions. periventricular white matter (PVWM). 0 = absent = "caps" or pencil-thin lining = smooth "halo" = irregular periventricular signal extending into the deep white matter A neuroradiologist evaluated the 3D T2-SPACE-FLAIR images to detect the presence of T2 hyperintensities and their degree (0: absent; 1: mild; 2: moderate; and 3: severe) for PVWM. Higher values represent a worse outcome.
outcome.population: Of the 68 patients that were randomized, 28 completed at least one light therapy session. 43 patients completed the study with at least one MRI scan. 19 subjects in the light treatment group and 24 subjects in the sham treatment group. One MRI was deemed low quality and excluded from analysis (19 light treatment / 23 sham)

group.title: Non-active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated. Non-active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied without light activated

measure.description: The presence of chronic white matter disease was evaluated using Fazekas scale. The scale divides the white matter in periventricular and deep white matter, and each region is given a grade depending on the size and confluence of lesions. periventricular white matter (PVWM). 0 = absent = "caps" or pencil-thin lining = smooth "halo" = irregular periventricular signal extending into the deep white matter A neuroradiologist evaluated the 3D T2-SPACE-FLAIR images to detect the presence of T2 hyperintensities and their degree (0: absent; 1: mild; 2: moderate; and 3: severe) for PVWM. Higher values represent a worse outcome.
measure.population: Of the 68 patients that were randomized, 28 completed at least one light therapy session. 43 patients completed the study with at least one MRI scan. 19 subjects in the light treatment group and 24 subjects in the sham treatment group. One MRI was deemed low quality and excluded from analysis (19 light treatment / 23 sham)

outcome.title: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on MRI Using the Fazekas Scale for Deep White Matter (DWM)
outcome.description: The presence of chronic white matter disease was evaluated using Fazekas scale. The scale divides the white matter in periventricular and deep white matter, and each region is given a grade depending on the size and confluence of lesions. deep white matter (DWM) 0 = absent = punctate foci = beginning confluence = large confluent areas A neuroradiologist evaluated the 3D T2-SPACE-FLAIR images to detect the presence of T2 hyperintensities and their degree (0: absent; 1: mild; 2: moderate; and 3: severe) for DWM. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

outcome.title: Neuroreactivity of Light Therapy to the Injured Brain Based on Neurcognitive Function
outcome.description: RPQ is a 16 item self-assessment questionnaire completed via an in-person or phone interview. Each item in the questionnaire is assessed on a 5-point scale ranging from 0 (no problem) - 4 (severe problem). The questions are grouped in two non-overlapping sets: the RPQ-3 includes early, objective, physical symptoms, and the RPQ-13 group includes later, more cognitive and behavioral symptoms. The RPQ-3 encompasses headache, dizziness, and nausea/vomiting. The RPQ-13 includes questions evaluating noise sensitivity, sleep disturbance, fatigue, irritability, depressed mood, forgetfulness, poor concentration, longer thinking time, blurred vision, light sensitivity, double vision, and restlessness. The RPQ-3 ranges from 0 - 12 (best to worst) and RPQ-13 ranges from 0 - 52 (best to worst). RPQ Total is the theoretical max/min RPQ score with a combined possible score ranging from 0-64 (best to worst). The outcome measures are

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were monitored/assessed during study enrollment through study completion, an average of 1 year.

group.title: Non-active LLLT Helmet Application
group.description: A helmet containing near infrared LED's (LLLT helmet) will be applied to the head, however, the LEDs will not be turned on / activated. Non-active LLLT helmet application: LED helmet applied without light activated

event.description: Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject came back to hospital due to pancreatitis
Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject went back to hospital due to MSSA bacteremia
Severe, expected, unrelated. During data review a SDH was discovered on study MRI which was not present on clinical CT.
Severe, expected, unrelated.

Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject went back to hospital due to suicidal ideation in the setting of intermittent depressive symptoms over years, chronic pain, and other difficulties. Evaluated and cleared by psychiatry.
Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject went back to hospital due to hemorrhagic cystitis.
Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject went back to hospital due to COPD exacerbation.
Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject came back for scheduled operation due to nonunion left distal tibial & fibular fracture
Severe, unexpected, unrelated. Subject went back to hospital due to rectal foreign body
Subject went back to hospital for cataract surgery
Subject went back to hospital due to neck pain.

Reporting of one or more of the following: Headache, blurred vision, double vision, dizziness, numbness, NV, ringing, noise, light, forgetfulness, thinking, concentrating, irritable, frustrated, restless, sleeping, fatigue, depressed.
Subject reported numbness/tingling in toes 1 week to 3 month time point
Subject went back to hospital due to dizziness
Hemorrhagic cyst
Subject visited urgent care for persistent cough
Subject went back to hospital due to alcohol abuse/intoxication.
Subject went back to hospital due to fall

event.sub_title: Glass from motor vehicle accident removed
event.description: Subject went back to hospital to have glass from motor vehicle accident removed from skin on forehead.
Subject went back to hospital to have broken nose corrected.
Subject went back to hospital for repair of zygomaticomaxillary complex (ZMC) and orbital floor fractures.
Subject went back to hospital for dislocated shoulder
Subject returned to hospital due to motor vehicle accident with diagnosis of shoulder sprain

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
